thread.title: Denver Pioneers fend off St. Cloud State’s rally, win in overtime.
thread.title_full: Denver Pioneers fend off St. Cloud State’s rally, win in overtime.

author: Terry Frei
title: Denver Pioneers fend off St. Cloud State’s rally, win in overtime.
text:
Capturing the spirit of the weekend commemoration of the 40th anniversary of the release of the classic film, “Slap Shot,” this is how veteran Charlestown Times Herald scribe Dickie Dunn might have described the University of Denver’s 4-3 overtime victory over St. Cloud State on Friday night at Magness Arena: “To see the three Pioneers make a scoring rush, the bright colors of their jerseys flashing against the milky ice, was to see a work of art in motion.” 
On the rush, prized Finnish freshman Henrik Borgstrom scored at 3:44 of the 5-on-5 overtime to give the top-ranked Pioneers their eighth consecutive win and make them 23-6-4. The setup pass for Borgstrom’s 16th goal of the season came from sophomore Troy Terry, who finished with a goal and two assists. 
“It was an odd man chance coming up,” Borgstrom said. “And when I see No. 19 (Terry) has the puck, I’m always sure that he will find me. I was coming late and he passed the puck to me. It was a little bit of a lucky goal, but I guess we deserved it. We had plenty of chances.” 
On Borgstrom’s shot, St. Cloud State goalie Jeff Smith, who finished with 34 saves, had a chance to clamp down on the puck under his arm, but it got through and into the net. 
“He was pretty frustrated because he had a couple of great opportunities that usually he doesn’t miss on,” DU coach Jim Montgomery said of Borgstrom. “The frustration was wearing on him, so for that one to squeak through, I think you could tell from his celebration how excited he was.” 
Sophomore center Dylan Gambrell had two goals for the Pioneers, who at the end of the night had a one-point lead over second-place Minnesota-Duluth in the National Collegiate Hockey Conference. 
“I thought it was a great game,” Montgomery said. “To me that’s a playoff game, an NCAA-type game where there’s momentum swings, there’s a lot of emotion in it.” 
Terry had the first DU goal, off a terrific blind backhanded pass from Borgstrom only 3:08 into the game. 
SCS took a 2-1 lead in the next five minutes on goals from Mikey Eyssimont and Jon Lizotte, but Gambrell made it 2-2 at 12:05 of the first before scoring again on a sneaky backhander through Smith’s five-hole in the early stages of he second. Related Articles
